scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Anne T. Lawrence Mine Workers Oral History Collection was a "Youthgrant" project from the National Endowment for the Humanities to the Miner's Voice, an independent newspaper for rank and file miners published in Charleston, WV. This collection contains the audio cassette oral histories carried out by Anne Lawrence, transcriptions, and the bound and printed final report.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In the 1920s-1930s, the central Appalachian coal fields were the scene of heavy industrial warfare. The coal operators believed that maintaining the open shop while under pricing their competitors would preserve their share of a dwindling market. The United Mine Workers (U.M.W.A.) needed to solidify the coal fields or face potential losses of previously unionized mines and operators. After World War I, union membership was at an all time high but the companies began implementing open shop techniques: labor injunctions, "yellow-dog" contracts, company spies, imported strikebreakers, company unions, and bribing local authorities. The union had always been strong in the hard coal fields in eastern Pennsylvania and the "Central Competitive" soft coal fields of Illinois, Ohio, Indiana, and western Pennsylvania. Due to lack of rail facilities and infrastructure, the southern fields of West Virginia, Virginia, Kentucky, and Tennessee, were late to develop and the union did not have a historical presence. As the demand for coal leveled off, the industry became plagued with chronic overproduction. Wages not protected by the union fell with the price of coal. In that economic market, the operators paying non-union wages maintained a competitive advantage over the union mines.

As more of the union mines were either bankrupting or repudiating their contracts, the U.M.W.A. decided that consolidating the Appalachian coal fields was of primary concern. Coal operators in that region, backed by private detective organizations, such as the Baldwin-Felts Agency, intimidated union organizers, blacklisted, fired, or physically assaulted miners, and maintained a strict control of the working conditions. In addition, operators typically paid the salaries of local sheriff offices, typically in the tonnage rate. With travel difficult, miners were very isolated from other mines and other labor movements.

Violence between the coal operators and miners during that time was extreme. Countless union organizers and sympathetic miners were murdered and beaten and eventually retaliated. The Matewan Massacre in Mingo County, West Virginia; the Battle of Blair Mountain in Logan County West Virginia; and the Battle of Evarts in Harlan County, West Virginia are all examples of this working class violence. The skirmishes mostly ended with the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933 and the efforts of then U.M.W.A. president John L. Lewis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Oral History Audio Cassettes include topics of mine operations during a period of heavy labor unrest. Topics include "Yellow-dog" contracts, blacklisting, wage gouging, strikes, corruption, and protests. There are discussions of union organizing with the United Mine Workers of America, the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the effects of the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933 and the efforst of John L. Lewis. There are discussions of violence from the local sheriffs, strike busters, private detectives such as the Baldwin-Felts Agency, coal miners and coal operators. Counties discussed are Harlan and Letcher Counties in Kentucky, and Logan, Boone, McDowell, and Mingo Counties in West Virginia.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series is arranged alphabetically by last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henry Clay Pettry lived in Lawson, West Virginia. Brother of Bill Pettry, U.M.W.A. District 17 Vice President, who shot Logan County Sheriff Don Chafin in 1919. Mr. Pettry discussed the lead up to and the events after the March on Logan and the Battle of Blair Mountain, living conditions in mining towns, and the efforts to organize union activity.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Interview was conducted by Anne T. Lawrence and the report can be found on page 19 of "On Dark and Bloody Ground".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Wilburn lived in Julian, West Virginia. He was convicted in Charles Town, West Virginia, along with Bill Blizzard, and several other union organizers, of murdering Deputy Sheriff John Gore during the Battle of Blair Mountain. Mr. Wilburn discussed the entire situation from the beginning, including the Matewan Massacre involving Sid Hatfield, the Baldwin-Felts Agency, and Ed Chambers, and the resulting violence in Logan County.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Interview was conducted by Anne T. Lawrence and the report can be found on page 23 of "On Dark and Bloody Ground".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Grace Jackson lived in Eskdale, West Virginia. A very self sufficient woman, Ms. Jackson participated in all union organization in Logan County. She discussed the highly prosperous days of the coal operators, and what economic opportunities were available to the women at that time. She talked of the Battle of Blair Mountain from a supporter's standpoint.

scopecontent.p: Camden McDornan lived in Brushton, West Virginia. He worked in Boone County in union mine territory but was part of the Battle of Blair Mountain. He discussed the organization of the battle and the resulting surrender to the National Guard.

He recalled the hardships of all miners, regardless of race, and the change in technology over the years. He worked in union mines and received his pension and is a strong union man.

He discussed the controversy surrounding the ending of the battle, and expressed a feeling that everyone has sold out. He was secretary of his local when he retired from a mine in Boone County.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Elbert Gore lived in Holden, WV. His father was deputy sheriff John Gore, who was shot by a group of miners during the Battle of Blair Mountain. Mr. Gore was a school teacher and was not involved with the law, but was taken hostage by miners regardless. He discussed the Battle of Blair Mountain, including the many times he felt his life was in danger. He eventually became a sheriff in spite of his previous experiences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dewey Browning lived in Switzer, West Virginia. Mr. Browning discussed the life of a union miner that played both sides. He had worked for Sheriff Don Chafin in the past which gave him the ability to avoid violence. He discussed the Battle of Blair Mountain as a nonparticipant and the aftermath of union organization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Howard Young lived in Holden, West Virginia. She was pregnant and giving birth during the Battle of Blair Mountain. Her husband Howard Young was involved in the march.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Josh Chafin lived in Cora, West Virginia. Mr. Chafin worked in mines but was forced to join the sides of the coal operators and the deputies. He stated that he did not want to fight, or get fired, so he went up to the Battle of Blair Mountain and did not participate. A veteran of World War I, he realized what he needed to do to stay alive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Swain lived in Charleston, West Virginia. A retired miner that sided with Sheriff Don Chafin, Mr. Swain became a reporter for the Logan Banner. He discussed in great detail the Battle of Blair Mountain. He also discussed living conditions and the power of the coal operators.

scopecontent.p: William Gothard lived in Cora, West Virginia. Mr. Gothard worked in the Logan County mines for over 50 years. He claimed to be a neutral and used his ability as a bootlegger to remain so. He discussed his interactions with his fellow miners and Sheriff Don Chafin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charles Literal lived in Logan, West Virginia. A retired miner, Mr. Literal was known as the local history buff. He retold the story of the Matewan Massacre and the Battle of Blair Mountain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pinhead Jones lived in Logan, West Virginia. Mr. Jones moved from Alabama and worked for the Island Creek Coal Company for nearly 40 years. He stated that Sheriff Don Chafin offered to pay him to fight against the miners, but refused and hid out throughout the Battle of Blair Mountain. He gave President Roosevelt all the credit for the miners' right to organize.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mary Ghiz lived in Logan, West Virginia. Her father, John Ghiz, immigrated to the United States in 1904 from Hungary. Her father was peddling clothes and eventually became Logan's first confectioner. Ms. Ghiz recalled the time of the Battle of Blair Mountain from a neutral viewpoint.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Georgie McCloud lived in Harts, WV. She wrote down her thoughts (included in the report) and most of the interview consists of her discussing her family's involvement in the Battle of Blair Mountain. Ms. McCloud's brother Wayne sided with the miners and her brother Gordon side with the coal operators and served as personal bodyguard to Sheriff Don Chafin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ira Hager lived in Meadowbrook Hills, West Virginia. Mr. Hager was a lawyer in Logan and handled murder cases in addition to preparing affidavits that detailed the violation of miners civil rights. He was part of a Republican coalition organized to break the strength of the coal industry Democratic dominated regime in the county.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Harry Dingess lived in Barnabus, West Virginia. He was a Sheriff under Don Chafin, but too young to participate in the Battle of Blair Mountain. Mr. Dingess then went on to work in the coal mines and discussed his life since.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Richard Burgett lived in Monaville, West Virginia. He worked in the mines in Mingo County and was threatened with a yellow dog contract. Although the miners in Mingo would heavily involved in striking and union organizing, they could not participate in the Battle of Blair Mountain as they would have had to pass through Logan and the route was blocked by private detectives. Mr. Burgett moved to Logan County in the 1920s and joined the union when the U.M.W.A. finally gained ground after the passage of the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933.

scopecontent.p: Bascombe Hyatt lived in Williamson, West Virginia. Mr. Hyatt worked in all sorts of mines, both union and nonunion, and earned a reputation as a scab. He claimed that a man has to provide for his family and does not see the need for unions if the men get paid regardless.

scopecontent.p: Edward Perry lived in Holden, West Virginia. Mr. Perry discussed living conditions in the mines under the Island Creek Coal Company and the #22 Holden mine explosion. He gave his perspective on the organization of unions and the scabs/union busters that came into town creating violent times. He also discussed the Battle of Blair Mountain, Matewan Massacre, and March on Logan incidents.

scopecontent.p: Sid Conley lived in Mud Fork, West Virginia. He worked for the Island Creek Coal Company and discussed the union organization struggles. He attributed the lack of organization to the authorities and their unrightfully persecution. Mr. Conley was a proud supporter of unions.

scopecontent.p: Mrs. L. Dow Browning lived in Verduneville, West Virginia. She discussed conditions during the early years of the union, specifically on the Gay Coal Company â€“ where her husband worked for over 60 years. The mine was not a union mine and the coal operators were against it, but she recollected that both the miners and the operators respected each other.

scopecontent.p: Otis Kinser lived in Logan, West Virginia. Mr. Kinser discussed the living conditions in Logan and the fear of the authorities and the force they used to deter union activity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lee Johnson lived in Monaville, West Virginia. Mr. Johnson discussed life in the mines of Logan County without a union, and how most miners did not have knowledge of organized labor. He talked about Sheriff Don Chafin and detailed the use of "shadow unions" until the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933. He stated that thousands turned out for the first organizing meeting in Logan.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Interview was conducted by Anne T. Lawrence and the report can be found on page 151 of "On Dark and Bloody Ground".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Elijah Mays lived in Holden, West Virginia. After starting out in the lumber business, Mr. Mays spent the majority of his life working in the mines of Logan County. A lifelong union man, he did not participate in the Battle at Blair Mountain as he would not raise arms against a fellow union miner. He suspects that most men were union men at heart, but the overbearing presence of Sheriff Don Chafin's deputies and the fear of arrest kept most men silent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frank Deen lived in Holden, West Virginia. After emigrating from Italy, Mr. Deen spent the majority of his life working the mines of the Island Creek Coal Company. A supporter of unions, he discussed living conditions and working conditions in the mines during the Depression, as well as life as an immigrant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Spencer and Laura Mullins lived in Verdunville, West Virginia. A lifelong miner around Omar, Mr. Mullins did not hear of union ideas until after returning from World War I. He states that the union sentiment really built up during the Depression. Mrs. Mullins discussed the life in the mining camps raising children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Shirley Workman lived in Mud Fork, West Virginia. Mrs. Workman's husband Issac worked over forty years for the Island Creek Coal Company. Mr. Workman joined the union prior to the Battle of Blair Mountain, but kept that information private for fear of persecution. Both Mr. Workman and two of his sons acquired black lung, and another was killed in a mine explosion at the #22 Holden mine. The Workman's see the coal companies as heartless bottom liners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Albert Williamson lived in Verdunville, West Virginia. Mr. Williamson worked in virtually all of the mines in Logan County until an accident forced early retirement in 1956. He discussed working conditions in non-union mines and how most miners could not wait for union organization that eventually came in 1933.

odd.head: General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nathan England lived in Monaville, West Virginia. Mr. England discussed living and working conditions of the mines in Tennessee. Similar to other miners, he was afraid to discuss union sentiment for fear of being fired and blacklisted. He recalled stories of union organizing in Tennessee which were similar to the stories of union organizing in West Virginia. He moved to the county in the late 1930's and worked in the mines for over 30 years.

Mr. Wilson was faced with major violence upon arrival, and did not appreciate the union structure and their inactivity during that time. He was then blacklisted and moved to Roda, VA, where he worked under a different name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Grant Howard lived in Evarts, Kentucky. Both Grant Howard and Red Poore were veterans of the union movement in Harlan County, Kentucky and the Battle of Evarts. One of the skirmishes in 1931 resulted in two men killed, and Mr. Poore was sentenced to life imprisonment but only served a 10 year sentence. Mr. Poore discussed the lack of a union presence in 1972, even though men fought and died for the right to organize. Mr. Howard moved on from the coal mines to the steel mines, where he has a longer commute but a higher standard of living.

scopecontent.p: John Bates lived in Whitesburg, Kentucky. Mr. Bates worked as an organizer for Letcher County in 1933 and was a strong union supporter. He discussed living conditions during very violent times and outlined the measures took by union organizers.

odd.p: Interview was conducted by Anne T. Lawrence and the report can be found on page 218 of "On Dark and Bloody Ground".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Luther King lived in Whitesburg, Kentucky. As an organizer for the U.M.W.A. from 1931-33, Mr. King handled most of southeastern Kentucky. He discussed the difficulty in organizing and the operation of feeding striking miners and their families.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Interview was conducted by Anne T. Lawrence and the report can be found on page 221 of "On Dark and Bloody Ground".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dewey Brown lived in Whitesburg, Kentucky. Mr. Brown worked as a volunteer organizer for the union in 1933 in Letcher County. He discussed the conditions of the mines prior to the union and the resulting conditions after the union was organized. He stated that only one union mine remained in 1972.

odd.head: General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Joe Ramsay lived in Monaville, West Virginia. He originally worked in the mines with his father in Letcher County, but moved Jenkins, Kentucky in 1933 where he was first exposed to the U.M.W.A. He eventually moved to Logan County, West Virginia, where he lived at the time of the interview.
